Literature Review: Visual dysfunction in diabetes is a complex condition that affects not only the vascular system but also the neuronal function of the retina. Diabetic retinopathy (DR) is a well-known complication of diabetes, but recent studies have shown that retinal neuronal and visual dysfunction can occur before the onset of vascular DR. This suggests that DR should be viewed as a neurovascular disease, where both vascular and neuronal components play a crucial role in the development of the disease. In this review, we will discuss the current understanding of visual dysfunction in diabetes, including the early changes in electroretinograms, contrast sensitivity, and neuronal mechanisms in rodent models of diabetes. We will also explore the potential implications of these findings for early diabetes treatments to ameliorate neuronal dysfunction.
